column4: i'm having trouble with a shell script. I need to take this string "+XX.0C" (Where , turn it into
oops
i'm having trouble with a shell script. I need to take this string "+XX.0C" (Where X is a number) , turn it into a pure number so i can add it to a sum
Have you tried sed?
no
Can you pastebin the script?
http://ubuntu.pastebin.com/m5d679817
I'm installing lm-sensors so I can see what your input's like.  :P
well that grep command gives me +66.0*C +67.0*C (Degrees sign, i can't do it) I have a dual core macbook
So are you trying to get an integer, or just trying to get rid of the + and the degrees celsius?
yes i want an interger. The number after decimal place is always a 0, so yeah an interger
Try the updated version here: http://ubuntu.pastebin.com/m1478d00d
All I've futzed with is the loop itself; the sed command strips it down to just the integer.  There are more elegant ways to do it, but that regexp should work as long as the input doesn't change.
it says /usr/bin/temp: line 17: syntax error near unexpected token `done'
Ah.  Get rid of the " ; done" at the end of the line I edited; it's redundant in the script.  In any case, the sed command should do what youw ant.
now it says Unexpected end of file
Again, I was working on the line by itself, rather than the whole script.  The thing to pay attention to is the sed command I added--it'll do the processing you want.
yeah thanks
no matter where i place the "done"(s) i can't get it to work

I'm sorry to say that's a logic problem.  I wish I had time to debug the whole script for you, but unfortunately I have to leave--just make sure you've got all your loops correctly matched (that is, a "do" for each "done" and likewise).
thanks alot
